reviewText: My 2 girls have every Barbie movie-they love them all, but this one is Mattels greatest one yet-they only got it last week and they have watched it day and night and now have become Erika and Annaliese-they glide through the house signing, dancing and acting out every scene from the movie-they even like the evil Preminger when he sings(I think Martin Short was great). The extra music disk in the DVD pack was a great idea too-the girls listen to it in the car and anywhere they can. The movie theme is more of a Broadway Musical format compared to the other Barbie movies. There is never a dull moment in this one-from the start of the movie it is fun and full of action, and innocent romance and it keeps you glued to the tube. The original story of Prince and the Pauper is not the same as this storyline, but this is an absolutely wonderful story. I would recommend it highly for girls ages 3 and up. HATS OFF TO YOU MATTEL getting better with every movie they come out with....keep em coming!!!!!

reviewText: My girls, ages 2 and 6, watched this movie every day since Christmas.  I am already learning the songs despite of myself and they love the audio CD that comes with the DVD.  I have to admit I love this movie.  Yes, it's cutesy.  Yes, it might be overdone, but it's just perfect for little girls.  I feel like one all over again when I watch with them.  I find myself singing the songs for them and they love that.The best part is that there is a sing along feature that the girls can watch as well as a Spanish language audio track.  Now hearing it in Spanish is cute too, even if the mouth movents don't quite match.  My only gripe is some not-so-polite words and name calling.Congratulations to Mattel for going the extra mile in producing a better quality kids movie when there is so much mediocre films out there.

reviewText: A pleasant surprise - a high quality production with lush musical numbers and lively voice characterizations.Animation is done by the so-called "performance-capture" technique using stand-ins to direct CGI avatars' gross movements, with closeups handled by human artists. Similar to the more widely-known "Polar Express" feature of 2004. Off-putting and a bit cardboardy for stage-drama purists, maybe, but the fantasy immersion works nevertheless.Martin Short as the voice of Preminger evidently had good fun with this villainous role -- a real treat. The other voices do very nicely, and the singing is clear and easy to sing along with using the accompanying "features" CD -- which my daughter plays often with great enthusiasm.Highly recommended!
summary: First-class for Younger Girls and Beyond

reviewerName: A. Woodley "Patroness, Janeites, the Austen list"
reviewText: The sign of a good movie is when you can watch it with your children and enjoy it - and this is one of those movies. This is Barbies first all singing all Dancing movie and they have done a great job. She moves well, she looks good, she sounds great and best of all they have got someone with a good sense of humour and excellent musician to do the music.This is the classic story retold with Barbie and a couple of cats. The Princess (Anneliese) and the Pauper Erika - they lead separate lives until one day they meet by accident. When Anneliese disappears mysteriously Erika is sought out again to take her place to try to prevent the wicked Preminger from his evil ways.Kids love this movie, it is bright, fun and has a pretty good story to keep them interested. My three year old loves it but it is pretty good for older ages as well - even boys enjoy it - but get rid of the wedding at the end which seems to be universally off-putting for most of them.I have got the Dolls which go with this and they are pretty nice, my girls play dress ups at the same time which is a nice tie in. One of the favourite movies in our house since Christmas!
summary: Superb - all singing, all dancing, great fun!

reviewText: Sometimes a marketing idea is just crass and without reedeming value.  But when the Barbie people hit on making computer-animated films featuring their characters, they did it right, and they still do.Like the earlier "Nutcracker," "Rapunzel," and "Swan Lake" films, our daughters are introduced to the classic arts in a way they can understand; in this case, Mark Twain's classic tale of a very poor youngster with nothing but a remarkable resemblance to a member of the royal family who would like nothing better than to get away from the responsibilities of royalty for awhile.  While two of the other films featured music quite heavily, being based on ballet, this one is done in the classic Hollywood/Broadway musical style, and the songs are as first-rate as anything you would expect from a big-budget Disney film (as opposed to this film, which could superficially be seen as nothing but a direct-to-video merchandising tool).Martin Short is featured as the bad guy, and as always, he has fun chewing on the scenery and earning the scorn of every viewer.  My little girl loves Wolfie, the barking cat; Sarafina, the elegant feline; Princess Annalise; her pauper double; and Herve, the aging heavy horse.  Oh yeah, there's a young king in town for an arranged marriage designed to save Annalise's kingdom from impending bankruptcy, and even my 7-year-old would say he's okay too.As a daddy I'm more interested in watching other films, of course, but this review is on behalf of my own little princess, who received this for her birthday less than a week ago and has watched it three times.  I could nitpick about the production from an adult perspective, but that's not the point.  My point here is that the Barbie people continue to produce high-quality entertainment for children that's consistently head and shoulders above most such product these days, and I'll never have the slightest reservation in letting my little girl indulge.There are those who may quibble about the political correctness of Barbies, and that's fine, but a 7-year-old girl couldn't care less about such things and is perfectly happy to engage in the princess fantasies represented here.  In any event, this story is modern enough that one of the characters chooses to pursue her career before getting married, so even the naysayers have to chew on that one for awhile.  Good stuff.
summary: There's still a place for fairy tales

reviewText: I just saw it on YTV Canada yesterday (2004. 12. 19), and I must say that I was quite surprisingly amused but pleased to see that Mattel and Mainframe had done an excellent job doing this musical, which is A Classic Barbie Twist on "The Prince and the Pauper" by Mark Twain.When I went through the movie, I thought that this musical really captured the essence of twin identities and true love as a well-done work. In this musical, Kelly Sharidan reprises her role of Barbie and does double duty as Pricess Anneliese and Erika, which is quite a challenge, whether it's live action or animation. You go, Kelly! (P.S. I thought that the outtakes and bloppers they added after the film were quite original, and they were kind of funny and interesting too! I guess they copied the idea from Toy Story 2.)Overall, I'd like to give it 5 of 5 Stars, with an A+ on my mind. Thanks, and that's for now. Bye!
summary: A Classic  Barbie Twist on "The Prince and The Pauper"(Rev.)

reviewText: This is a great film for girls of any age, not just the "10 and under" group.  I enjoy it and I'm over 21 (way over 21). In fact, I remember the original Barbie dolls, so I'm qualified to compare the development of Barbie in the early 60's to the Barbie of today, and I can attest to the fact that the Barbie in "The Princess and the Pauper" empowers young girls to dream, to take charge of their own lives, to take risks and push boundaries.  This Barbie loves science and exploration, she studies math and geography, and she uses her brains and education to save her kingdom. Way to go, Barbie!About the film itself, I find it enchanting and light-hearted, and I'm not ashamed to say that I play it a lot.  It makes me feel good.  It's fun. I enjoy it, and I'm playing it for me, not for any children in the house.  I want to create a positive atmosphere in my home, and this is one of the tapes that I play to create that upbeat, positive atmosphere.Martin Short gives a deliciously evil performance as Preminger.  In Preminger's speech patterns, I hear hints of Martin's character "Frahnk" from "Father of the Bride" and I'm impressed by his versatility in delivering various accents. All the characters are well-developed and distinctive.  I am full of admiration for the makers of this production.

reviewText: It is amazing how many times I have watched this film, in the company of my two daughters, and yet I have never grown tired of it.  The Broadway-style musical numbers are tuneful, memorable, and first-rate.  The computer animation is a visual delight.  And the new spin on the old Mark Twain story makes the plot captivating and fresh.Best of all is the vocal contribution of Martin Short at the villain Preminger.  Short's glee in playing this part is palpable.  I only wish there were a DVD extra showing him in the recording studio as he laid down his tracks...I am confident that he was practically bouncing off the walls as he went so far over the top he came back around through the floor.  His performance alone makes this a film that will endure long after most of its genre are forgotten.  What a showman!Buy this for your kids, but don't tell them you'll enjoy it just as much as they will.  They won't count it as a gift if you admit that.
summary: THIS is why Barbie was born!

reviewText: I never thought I would find myself reviewing a Barbie DVD, but I felt like this one was too good to not write a favorable review.My daughter, Emma, wanted to see it so reluctantly I added it to our rental selections."Oh, joy," I thought, "Hopefully she will not watch it when I am around."Much to my surprise, these two beautiful young women actually solve their problems without "the big, strong man" coming to the rescue! WOW! Now this is novel! They sing about their destiny, they take responsibility and stand for inspired duty, not drudgery.I love the music and the "More Fun" section of the DVD can entertain my daughter (and me) for hours.If my daughter wants to watch material in this genre, I would be MORE than happy for her to watch this DVD repeatedly. The animation is spectacular, the music exceptional and the "acting" in the animation simply works.

reviewText: The Barbie movies just keep getting better and better...from the Nutcracker and Rapunzel to Swan Lake and The Princess and the Pauper, each movie brings charm and excitement to a classic story.  One thing that I especially love about these movies is that they take stories that aren't as well-known as some other fairy tales and bring them to an eager audience.In The Princess and the Pauper, Anneliese is a princess longing to see the world outside the castle walls before she is married to King Dominick of the neighboring kingdom.  She ventures out into the city with her tutor, Julian, and befriends a poor girl by the name of Erika who is her virtual twin.  When Anneliese is kidnapped by the evil Preminger, who wants to marry the princess himself, Erika is called on by Julian to impersonate the princess so that they can stall for time to unravel the truth.  This brings about lots of adventure and romance as King Dominick finds himself falling for Erika and Julian tries to rescue his best friend, the princess.  There are definitely strong, self-sufficient women in this Barbie movie as evidenced by the ending, when one of the girls decides she must follow her dreams before marrying her prince.I also love the animals...Anneliese's Seraphina and Erika's Wolfie (the cat who barks) have a little thing of their own going, and I thought that Midas, the puffy, swanky little mean poodle was hilarious.The singing is great, the animation is beautiful, as usual...this is just a first class movie.  You will love it as much as your little girl does.
summary: Another classic movie in the Barbie series

reviewText: While we love all the Barbie movies, this one is my least favorite.  The singing is nice but overdone.  I know it's a musical, but they seemed to turn every scene into a singathon, which got annoying and interrupted the flow of the story, in my opinion.That said, all in all, a well done movie - and yes, I want my daughters to have someone with grace, politeness, and self-control as a role model, to answer the "skunk at the garden party" reviewer.The girls DID stand up for what was right once they knew exactly what was going on.  We as the audience were privvy to the plans of the bad guy, but the heroines didn't know right away.  Of course their hair was unruffled after "action" - have you ever seen a cartoon character look mussed up except after a bomb went off or something????This is a nice movie and I would have given it 5 stars except I think the songs were over-done just a bit...and my six year old son loves all the Barbie movies too (that goes with having two sisters, I guess.  He doesn't think of them as "girl" movies, just like they don't consider Batman, Spiderman, or Speed Racer "boy" movies.)
summary: Another Winner, but not the Best of the Lot

reviewerName: Katie C. Nelson "Katie the Scrapbook Lady"
reviewText: We actually have enjoyed all the Barbie movies but this was the best one they have come out with so far.  I was a little skeptical when I heard it was a musical, but the songs are well done and have very positive messages.  Including the music cd with the movie was a wonderful bonus (nice that we didn't have to buy that separately!)The folks at Mattel are truly marketing geniuses when it comes to this whole Barbie movie thing they have going on.  Each year they release a new movie (and of course a plethora of Barbie merchandise related to it) and they seem to know their target audience.  The stories they have told are timeless classics but with a more up to date spin on them.  I love what they did with the Prince and the Pauper story...the princess and her look-a-like were genuinely good characters in strong female roles.  They wanted to do what was right for others and for themselves.  I also appreciated the parts played by the male lead characters (Julian & Dominick) because they were respectful of the females in the movie and also good role models in their own, but limited roles.The villain is played to perfection by Martin Short.  He is way over the top of course, but I would expect nothing less from Martin Short!  I don't know who voiced the other characters but they all did a good job and the singing was beautiful.I give this 5 stars because it is just right for the audience they have intended it for - perfect for little girls of any age.  If they would have had these movies around when I was a girl I would have gone crazy over them!  I have to admit that I have enjoyed watching this with my daughter and I have even willingly watched it more than once.  I wish there were more kid movies that I could say that about.
summary: The best of the Barbie movies
Title: N/A

reviewText: I was definitely surprised by Barbie's take on "The Prince And The Pauper" tale.  The title was conveniently changed to "Princess" so that our beloved heroine could tackle the role wholeheartedly.  Anyway, this is definitely the best of all of the Barbie movies out there.When I first popped this one into the DVD player for my daughter, I expected something similar to the other Barbie flicks:  great choreography, decent animation, bland story with a happy ending, and one modestly popular voice.  Well, Martin Short provided the modestly popular voice, the animation was pretty good, and, as usual, the choreography was brilliant.  However, the story was nowhere near bland.The story has been told time and again.  The princess, played by Barbie, wants to get away from her royal responsibilities and live life like a normal person.  The pauper, also played by Barbie in a great dual performance(ha, ha), on the other hand, struggles to get by and would do anything to get a shot at the easy life.  Well, the princess and the pauper swap places by way of the princess being captured in a maniacal scheme for Short's character to become king.  The pauper pretends to be the princess long enough to thwart Short's plans and to give time for the the princess' aid(played by a dashing Ken, also in a dual role) to figure out exactly what is going on.  From there, we are treated to some light humor, romance, truth and lies.  It all ends happily, as expected, but I won't give anymore details.Granted, this movie is definitely geared towards the kids and it is a great marketing tool for the Barbie toyline, but it is a fun film to watch.  I never got bored with it.  It kept my attention for the complete running time and I was amazed at how well the story was actually played out.Recommended to folks with little girls who love Barbie(obviously), but if you don't have children, you might want to stay away.  I like it and give it four stars, but those four stars are based on the comparison to the existing Barbie films, so don't let the rating fool you.  Thanks for reading.

reviewText: After having seen the first three Barbie movies, I was hoping this one would be worth the money I spent on it, and I wasn't disappointed.  The storyline is very well-written, the songs are catchy, and the costumes are gorgeous.  However, it still bothers me that the girl who's supposed to be a pauper is wearing a very elegant gown, but that's another story.  The choreography was lovely to watch, especially when Erika and Anneliese were twirling in opposite directions from a bird's eye view, showing Anneliese in a pink dress with a blue cape in the back, and Erika in a blue dress with a pink design in the center.  It kind of showed visually how the two girls were similar yet different at the same time.The DVD I got came with a bonus CD containing the songs of the movie, and that made me very happy, since the songs do get better the second and third times you hear them.  The music is lovely, and there are also karaoke tracks on the DVD, but without hearing Barbie singing, the songs are EXTREMELY difficult for a person to sing on her own because the lyrics go by so quickly, and the words aren't highlighted individually like on some singalong tracks, so small children may want to avoid this feature unless they know the songs by heart.All-in-all, it's a very heartwarming movie and definitely the best so far, even though it's far more realistic than the fantasy themes of the previous three movies.
summary: Very good for a direct-to-video movie

reviewText: I just saw this one and I have to say I was pleasantly surprised.  I knew my daughter would love it, but I didn't expect to like it as well.  The story was sweet and I thoroughly enjoyed it.  My daughter was particularly delighted with the singing.  She loves to sing, and musicals lend themselves for repeated encores by my daughter who learns songs faster than I ever could.  If you have never watched a Barbie movie, I would recommend you give them a try, especially if you have a little girl in your home.  They are much better than what most people who have not watched them think they are.  The messages in the movies are positive, and the movies themselves are captivating and well made.  As a parent I can say that I do not get as tired of the Barbie movies as I do of most other cartoon movies when forced to watch them repeatedly by my child.  That is a big plus in my book.  Barbie Princess and the Pauper is a nice follow up film to the other Barbie movies.  We look forward to the next installment in the series.Also recommended: Barbie and the Nutcracker, Barbie as Rapunzel, and Barbie in Swan Lake

reviewText: My daughter received this lovely dvd for her 4th birthday and we have already watched it three times in one week! The folks at Mattel have truly outdone themselves again with this engaging musical/fantasy story based on "The Prince and the Pauper" story.Princess Anneliese wants nothing more than to be free of the constraints of being 'royal' while commoner Erika wishes to be free of her poverty and position as an indentured servant for the mean Madame Kamp.  Their wishes are granted when Preminger (voiced by Martin Short) kidnaps Princess Anneliese so that he can assert his influence on the queen and become king.  Erika steps in to take the princess' place so that Julian (Anneliese's tutor and secret admirer) can bide his time and find out who took Anneliese.  In the meantime, Erika (as Anneliese) meets the handsome King Dominic and they fall in love.The story is resolved in true G/PG Barbie/Disney style and our heroes and heroines live happily ever after. However, what makes this film a real treat is its catchy songs (my daughter has been singing "I'm Just Like You" non-stop since the day she first saw this movie), memorable characters and engaging plot. Add to this the beautiful CGI work that transports you into colorful and magical fairytale.Like its Barbie dvd predecessors, "The Princess and the Pauper" is a great addition to our family film library and I highly recommend it to young Barbie fans and their parents for its wholesomeness and entertainment value. Here's looking forward to the next Barbie venture!

reviewText: I was forced to watch this while over at a friends place. Her 5-year old is definitely into the whole princess thing and did like it a lot. I didn't hate it and the story was more interesting than I would expect with something with Barbie as the main character. The only thing is that I'm at a loss to see us inundating our little girls with the whole "Princess" ideal - especially since the whole real life princess deal is no fairy tale - see Princess Diana's life for proof of this.  Why not make a picture with young girls/women as honorable knights incognito or out to save the world a la brillian boy genius Jimmy Neutron or as "Jemma" Hawkins in a different version of Treasure Island or even a young woman version in The Three Musketeers.  Can't we show girls at that very impressionable age that they can aspire to be more than mere princesses who find happiness with their perfect Prince Charmings?  Give the girls better role models to look up to. My favorite kids movies when I was little were The Dark Crystal, The Secret of N.I.M.H. and The Rescuers.

reviewText: When my wife called me to ask if I minded her getting this video for my three-year-old daughter, I of course told her that it was fine.  I knew I would be stuck watching it over and over because my little girl loves to watch things with her daddy.  We sat down before bedtime and popped it in the VCR, and I committed myself to being a good daddy and to spending some quality time with my little one.  The movie opened with a rip-roaring musical number, and the quality of the computer animation was very impressive.  Being a Mark Twain scholar (I did my thesis on Twain), I was expecting a goofy, silly movie adaptation of the story.  After all, Barbie is about as interesting to me as fly vomit.  However, what I found was a wonder.  The story was excellent, but the songs were the best part of the film.  The quality of the musical numbers rivals that of any Disney production.  The VHS tape came with a CD with all of the major songs on it.  My little girl sits and sings them to me and even asks her dad to join in on the "boy parts" of the song.  What struck me about the movie most was the excellent character development in this short film.  It was, I have to reluctantly admit, wonderful.  Princess Annaliese, Erika, King Dominick, Julian, and the two cats are wonderfully portrayed.  However, the stand out character is most definitely Preminger.  This is a top-notch villain because he dosen't fit the established mold.  He is prissy, vain, and feminine.  However, he is also sly, conniving, and cruel hearted.  His musical number "How can I refuse?" is among the best "villain songs," I have ever heard...bar none.  There is also a great subplot involving the cats.  Even the minor characters stand out.  I've watched the film over and over with my little girl, and I have to admit that I enjoyed it every time.  And I don't feel a bit unmanly at all.
summary: Great, even if you are a manly man.

reviewText: My daughter is 6 and my son is 4 and they love this movie. I even sat down to watch it and I was so captured. The plot keeps you on your toes.  The music is so beautiful. My daughter knows almost all the words to the songs, you can sing along with the subtitles if you want to. She just sings over and over every day.  This is a must have for any little girl.

reviewText: This is a great movie. It has been my 6 year old's favorite since she was 3 years old. She wanted to borrow it so much we just bought it on Amazon so we could have it at home. A good telling of a Mark Twain classic. Great music too. My daughter loves to sing along with Barbie. A Good Buy.

reviewText: My daughter loves all of the Barbie movies. This is a very good one as are the others. I watch them with her and we have quality father-daughter time. I will always cherish these times.
